title: England stars would go down in history with football's line in the sand action on racism
text:

Finally, the line in the sand football has been crying out for.

The cards on the table to at last make clear enough is enough.

You almost want the worst to come to the worst so that Gareth Southgate’s England stars can write their names into history by placing principle above playing on if they are racially abused yet again.

Walking off would send out a message that would reverberate far beyond Prague or serial offenders Bulgaria. It would empower young men in the Premier League, set a consistent new benchmark for action in Serie A, Spain and the other big competitions.

Whether he is leading from the front of harnessing the fire of his militant young stars, Gareth Southgate deserves credit for allowing them to do what needs to be done unshackled by the rules which simply do not protect black footballers.

(Image: AFP/Getty Images)

(Image: Action Images via Reuters)

England’s stars are fed up with having to rise above the kind of racist abuse they’ve come to expect on away trips for club or country. Football’s right-thinking contingent is sick of having to see and hear it.

We’ve all had a bellyful of FIFA and UEFA - with so little black representation at decision-making level - remaining so incapable of applying the kind of punishments that act as a deterrent.

The time for soundbites, handwringing and calls to leave it to the authorities has been over for some time.

(Image: Getty Images)

(Image: PA)

Supporters intent on racially abusing players don’t care enough about the consequences.

What do they have to fear when the fat cats at the top of the game are so weak? It is an embarrassment to this industry that racism is even an issue in 2019.

So walk off and hang the consequences. Good luck to UEFA trying to hold on to their sponsors if they try to punish the England players too.

What commercial entity would want to be aligned to a body trying to hammer players protesting at being racially abused?

(Image: EMPICS Sport)

Out of the chaos can come a new order that ensures black stars no longer have to put up with the kind of thing they wouldn’t in any other industry.

The protocols don’t work. Players like Mario Balotelli and Sulley Muntari have tried to follow it in the past and have ended up being punished themselves.

England Under-17 coach Steve Cooper tried to follow it two years ago when Rhian Brewster claimed Morgan Gibbs-White had been racially abused by a Spanish player during the Under-17 World Cup final. FIFA ruled there was no case to answer.

(Image: Getty Images Europe)

(Image: FIFA)

The fines don’t work. Serie A issued a punishment of just under £9,000 to Italian club Atalanta on Tuesday after a section of their fans racially abused Fiorentina's Dalbert.

Last year Russia were made to pay just £22,000 for the monkey chants directed at Paul Pogba and France during their international in St Petersburg.

What will work is action. Football needs a sea change. Everyone has had enough.
description: England's players are ready to walk off if they are racially abused and it would sent out a message to the whole world - enough is enough
